newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Eight African states start military exercise.
newsitem.headline: Eight African states start military exercise.

text.p: Eight central and southern African states launched a military exercise in Zimbabwe on Friday, the first of its kind in Africa aimed at coordinating their peacekeeping operations.

Some 1,100 troops from Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania and Zimbabwe -- all Commonwealth members -- are taking part in the 20-day exercise in Zimbabwe's mountainous Nyanga district.

London's Zimbabwe-based British Military Advisory and Training Team is helping to run the exercise, code-named Blue Hungwe (Bird), which it says demonstrates its "commitment to the development of regional peacekeeping operations in Africa".

Zimbabwe Defence Minister Moven Mahachi told a launching parade that participating nations were keen to cooperate, as urged by the Organisation of African Unity and United Nations, to try to establish lasting peace in Africa.
Britain's Prince Andrew is scheduled to visit Zimbabwe on April 15 for three days to preside at the closing parade of the exercise, which is jointly funded by Britain.

"The aim of the exercise is to enhance regional African liaison, cooperation and military skills by means of multinational joint field training exercise based on the United Nations tactics and techniques of international peacekeeping," the British embassy (High Commission) said in a statement.
